_comment_1: # Typist 3.0 - improved typing tutor program for UNIX systems

seriesMenu.title: This series contains the following lessons

entries.title: Lesson D2     Learning the shift key
Lesson D3     Home row and the period
Lesson D4     Upper row and essential punctuation
Lesson D6     Learning the lower row

D1.1.title: Lesson D1.1: Tutorial
text: Welcome to the Dvorak Course
This course has been planned for beginners as well as experienced typists.
If you are a beginner learning to type on the American Simplified Keyboard
(the Dvorak keyboard), you will find this keyboard easier to learn than
the QWERTY (Sholes) keyboard.
This is because the ASK has been scientifically designed to minimize cumulative
finger motion while typing English.  The ten letters on the Home Row
(A, O, E, U, I, D, H, T, N, and S) make up about 70% of all keystrokes.
These ten letters alone can form over 3000 words.  Needless to say, having
these keys in the home row facilitates both speed and accuracy.
If you are already an experienced typist on the Sholes keyboard, don't despair:
you won't have to unlearn everything you know.  Your basic typing dexterity
remains with you, regardless of the keyboard layout.  Learning the Dvorak
keyboard is like learning to "play on a new surface", as a tennis player must
learn to adjust to grass court or hard court when she has been accustomed to
playing on a clay court.

D1.2.title: Lesson D1.2: Tutorial
text: General Instructions
The fingers of the left hand should be placed over the A-key, the O-key,
the E-key, and the U-key.  Similarly, the fingers of the right hand should be
placed over the H-key, the T-key, the N-key, and the S-key.

D2.1.title: Lesson D2.1: Tutorial
text: Learning the Shift Key
To integrate the shift key rhythmically in your practice, a capital letter
should take three beats: 1--press the shift key opposite the hand to press
the letter; 2--press the letter; 3--release the shift key.

D3.1.title: Lesson D3.1: Tutorial
text: Home Row and the Period
The period is above the E-finger.  Note that the end of a sentence is
always followed by two spaces; in abbreviations, it is followed by one
space.

D3.5.title: Lesson D3.5: Drill
text: In the house Adana dined in haste on toast and dates.
Sated as she had eaten she noted the sheen on the dunes
asd the shade in the sheds.  She hates to see an idiot
stand and shoot his tenth doe in the dense heath.

D3.6.title: Lesson D3.6: Drill

to douse teeth and hoist suede hoods onto heads.

D4.5.title: Lesson D4.5: Drill
text: Can pa go aft and lie on our old cot?
The shy ape put on a red hat and ran off the lot.
For a top fee, her act is to hop in, lie on the rug, pat her
pet cat, fit a fur on her ear, get her fan, and run off.

D5.1.title: Lesson D5.1: Drill
text: The left road can lead the lads and lady to good lots near
your land.  The sale of pure gold is held at your door.

D5.2.title: Lesson D5.2: Drill
text: You held no fear of loss for a year.  On each trip to your
shop he paid in cash for the caps, fish, cups, pans, fuel,
logs, peas, ales, rice and fats you sold.

D5.3.title: Lesson D5.3: Drill
text: It is a fact that a slap on the face can hurt.  The poor
apes feel free to find a sure sort of life in the dale.

D7.1.text: In a daze the band hums the same new tune as they zoom down the exit.

D7.2.title: Lesson D7.2: Drill
text: Next time, I must have a town home, with a book and a vast tome,
bees, oxen, hams in the oven, rows of beans, the wind and a view.

D7.3.title: Lesson D7.3: Drill

their jobs when the job zone size is too wide.

D9.4.text: My big boy may buy a gem at the labs by the bay.

elks and game, row a yawl, or ram awls into bars.

D10.1.title: Lesson D10.1: Drill
text: In barns on farms chicks, boars, veals, bucks and stock might
enjoy and value an extra quart of water daily.

D10.2.title: Lesson D10.2: Drill
text: Do zebras roam the miles of bleak velds which cover parts of the
world while packs of brown bears and wart hogs prowl in the woods?

D10.3.title: Lesson D10.3: Drill
text: Some folks claim to favor poems and rhyme, others can wring equal
cheer and worth from words and quest and seize all books.  Still
others amply quell their needs with vocal music and seek all
works on voice.

D10.4.title: Lesson D10.4: Drill
text: To begin to use wrong verbs among boors and bores may be
a severe error even if the whole group seems to think
that exact terms mean less than is normal for them.

D11.1.title: Lesson D11.1: Drill
text: For a meal we lack a room, milk in mugs, warm pork, veal
in the oven and cake.

D11.2.title: Lesson D11.2: Drill
text: Mike and Milt were grim, not calm, when Mort came to warn them that
the well worn ramp over to the mill was too wet for our mile walk.

D11.3.title: Lesson D11.3: Drill
text: Walt may quip and quote with zeal about too much work, but I
saw him melt and mourn about his love for his lost wife.

D11.4.title: Lesson D11.4: Drill
D11.4.text: The pick of wool from rams can make very soft warm garb.

D11.5.title: Lesson D11.5: Drill
text: For his meal the busy bird will use his bill or beak in many
ways to peck at or ably to pick up a worm.

D11.6.title: Lesson D11.6: Drill
text: Owls on the wing may move away with limp easy grace or they
may sit on a wire and look ever so wise.

D11.7.title: Lesson D11.7: Drill
text: The word or term--prop, mall, king, mark, romp, lock or link--
can vary in what it may mean.

D12.1.title: Lesson D12.1: Drill
text: In barns on farms chicks, bears, veals, bucks and stock might
enjoy and value an extra quart of water daily.

D12.2.title: Lesson D12.2: Drill
text: Quick quips, awful quotes and queer talks never quite solve
the wants of a very small child.

D12.3.title: Lesson D12.3: Drill
text: Do zebras roam the miles of bleak velds which cover parts of the
world while packs of brown bears and wart hogs prowl in the woods?

D12.4.title: Lesson D12.4: Drill
text: Some folks claim to favor poems and rhyme, others can wring equal
cheer and worth from words and quest and seize all books.  Still
others amply quell their needs with vocal music and seek all
works on voice.

D12.5.title: Lesson D12.5: Drill
text: The queen was given a query for which an ample reply would
take a quire of paper.

D12.6.title: Lesson D12.6: Drill
text: Six husky cooks boiled clam broth, shrimp and prawns and broiled
liver for seven lucky elves, then made their hasty exits.

D12.7.title: Lesson D12.7: Drill
text: At the games, Mark was so very badly hurt with many broken bones,
lumps on his jaws, and some glands burst.  Blood oozed from a crack
in his wart where it had oozed for weeks.  He was lucky to have lived.

D12.8.title: Lesson D12.8: Drill
text: To check pomp and pride, sever from all overt vices, belay all
forms of muck raking, and limit all hazards, will bring prime joy.

D12.9.title: Lesson D12.9: Drill
text: To begin to use wrong verbs among boors and bores may be
a severe error even if the whole group seems to think
that exact terms mean less than is normal for them.

D13.1.title: Lesson D13.1: Tutorial
text: The following 135 words are so frequently used that they comprise 50%
of all words normally typed.  If you can type the next two exercises without
errors, half of your typed words will be correct!

been before being between both but by can could day did do down each

D13.4.title: Lesson D13.4: Tutorial
D13.4.text: We now concentrate on home row words.

D13.5.title: Lesson D13.5: Drill
text: The duteous dietitian hesitated at the intense nauseousness inside
the dishonest institution.

D13.6.title: Lesson D13.6: Drill
text: In addition, the unastute assassin had another unsound idea.  He
intended to assassinate the dishonest attendant at the institute.

D13.7.title: Lesson D13.7: Drill
text: The unintentioned noisiness and untidiness in the hostess house
astonished, astounded and nauseated Antonietta.  Undaunted and
unassisted, she did not hesitate to initiate a statute at the state
house.  The statute stated that no attendant in an untenanted haunted
hostess house is to attain hostess status.

D14.1.title: Lesson D14.1: Tutorial
D14.1.text: In this lesson we practice alphabetic sentences.

D14.2.title: Lesson D14.2: Drill
D14.2.text: Sixty-five quizzical sheep kept their jaws dry in a farm bungalow.

D14.3.title: Lesson D14.3: Drill
D14.3.text: Balky Zulus find they can hoax weary men with quavery jumping.

D14.4.title: Lesson D14.4: Drill
D14.4.text: Jerome quickly began to be vexed by the powerful blizzards.

D14.5.title: Lesson D14.5: Drill
D14.5.text: Squawking gorillas could vex the brazen nymphs in a jiffy.

D14.6.title: Lesson D14.6: Drill
D14.6.text: Can Jerry's equipment file saws, ax, hoe, knives and grind adz?

D14.7.title: Lesson D14.7: Drill
D14.7.text: Ben works at squeezing very juicy plums with flexed thumbs.

D14.8.title: Lesson D14.8: Drill
D14.8.text: The black wizard quipping jovially flexed his muscles.

D14.9.title: Lesson D14.9: Drill
D14.9.text: Will you pack my jugs of liquid veneer in five dozen boxes?

D14.10.title: Lesson D14.10: Drill
D14.10.text: Could the wizard jinx quivering folks by magic yelps?

D14.11.title: Lesson D14.11: Drill
D14.11.text: Brazen gazelles quickly examined the forward jeep.

D14.12.title: Lesson D14.12: Drill
D14.12.text: The brown dog quickly jumped over the lazy fox.

D14.13.title: Lesson D14.13: Drill
D14.13.text: Will the kind judge squelch the five or six brazen nymphs?

D14.14.title: Lesson D14.14: Drill
D14.14.text: Mix zippy Kadota figs with quivering cranberry jelly.

D14.15.title: Lesson D14.15: Drill
D14.15.text: The wives quickly jerked extra big pizzas from the stand.

D14.16.title: Lesson D14.16: Drill
D14.16.text: Lisa quickly mixed the very big jar of new soap.

D14.17.title: Lesson D14.17: Drill
D14.17.text: The major will fix a quiet cozy nook for the vexed, bad Gypsy.

D14.18.title: Lesson D14.18: Drill
D14.18.text: Pairs of lazy knowing oxen came by quietly evading the jam.

D14.19.title: Lesson D14.19: Drill
D14.19.text: Juvenile zest for excitement whetted interest in parking by the quay.

D14.20.title: Lesson D14.20: Drill
D14.20.text: Put your big ax, shovel and quartz where Mike's fence joins ours.

D14.21.title: Lesson D14.21: Drill
D14.21.text: The brawny jaguar held fast till the quaking Zouave victim expired.
